How to get to NCCB

About

THE NCCB is the Northern California Computational Biology student group for PhD, masters, and undergraduate students based in Northern California.

Students from UC Berkeley, UC Santa Cruz, UCSF, and Stanford NCCB produce a one-day symposium of student and industry talks, a poster session, and networking opportunities that encompass all fields related to computational biology.

The 2017 NCCB symposium will take place on Saturday, October 7th on Science Hill at the University of California Santa Cruz.

#NorCalCompBio2017 Tweets

Faculty Speaker

Angela Brooks

Angela Brooks is an Assistant Professor of Biomolecular Engineering at UC Santa Cruz whose research group focuses on identifying cancer genome alterations that disrupt gene regulation, particularly through the regulation of RNA splicing. They are developing computational approaches to analyze genome and transcriptome sequencing data and developing high-throughput experimental approaches to characterize the functional impact of cancer variants. Dr. Brooks received her Ph.D. in molecular and cell biology with a designated emphasis in computational and genomic biology at UC Berkeley with Dr. Steven Brenner, then was a postdoctoral fellow at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and the Broad Institute in the laboratory of Dr. Matthew Meyerson. In recognition of her work, Dr. Brooks was named a Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation Merck Fellow and also received the Dale F. Frey Award for Breakthrough Scientists.

For her keynote faculty lecture opening the NCCB conference, Dr. Brooks will discuss her research as well as pass on some knowledge to young scientists.

Directions

Conference Location

The conference will be held at the UC Santa Cruz Baskin Auditorium (Room 101).

Parking

There is free event parking in the Core West parking lot nearby. There is also street parking for vehicles greater than 8' tall and long vehicles.

Registration

The registration for the conference.

Sponsorship Information

Interested in Sponsoring NCCB 2017?

The Northern California Computational Biology (NCCB) Student Symposium is a great event to access the computational biology student community and to promote your organization directly to conference attendees. Please consider partnering with us in sponsoring this important scientific and educational event.

Sponsorship Levels

We are requesting sponsorship at the following levels. All sponsor representatives are welcome to attend all symposium talks, poster session and reception.

Gold Level ($2,000+)
  • Conference passes for up to four representatives to attend symposium
  • Opportunity for roundtable meetings with students
  • Access to resumes from opt-in attendees
  • Tables to use to exhibit your materials
  • Distribution of promotional materials to all attendees
  • Corporate name and logo will be displayed on NCCB website and printed materials
Silver Level ($1,000+)
  • Conference passes for up to two representatives to attend symposium
  • Access to resumes from opt-in attendees
  • Table to use to exhibit your materials
  • Distribution of promotional materials to all attendees
  • Corporate name and logo will be displayed on NCCB website and printed materials
Bronze Level ($500+)
  • Conference pass for a representative to attend the symposium
  • Shared table to use to exhibit your materials
  • Corporate name and logo will be displayed on NCCB website and printed materials

Other Sponsorship Opportunities

If you are interested in supporting the NCCB Student Symposium but would like to inquire about sponsoring the event in other ways, such as providing a smaller amount of donation for coffee, lunch, t-shirts, or providing other giveaways to conference attendees, please feel free to contact us at: nccbsymposium@gmail.com.

Schedule

This is the planned schedule for the conference. Subject to change!

Agalma

Agalma is our multifunctional phylogenetic analysis tool. We use it to build phylogenies from genome and transcriptome data, and to study the evolution of differential gene expression. The photo above is of an Agalma, the siphonophore that this tool is named after.

Siphonophores.org

Our site about siphonophores.
